content: The Act is known as the "Grant Reporting Efficiency and Agreements Transparency Act of 2018" or the "GREAT Act" and its purpose is outlined in Section 2. The GREAT Act aims to modernize reporting for recipients of Federal grants and cooperative agreements by imposing data standards, implementing recommendations for standard definitions, and reducing burden and compliance costs through technology solutions. The GREAT Act aims to improve data management for Federal grants and cooperative agreements through technology solutions and standardized open data access for better oversight and transparency. The GREAT Act introduces data standards for grant reporting in the United States Code, aiming to enhance oversight and transparency in Federal grants and cooperative agreements. The GREAT Act introduces data standards for grant reporting in the United States Code, defining key terms like agency, core data elements, Director, and Federal award. The curr_chunk defines the public purpose of support or stimulation authorized by US law, including financial assistance, grants, awards, and cooperative agreements, but excludes certain types of direct government cash assistance, subsidies, loans, and loan guarantees. The curr_chunk defines terms such as Secretary, standard-setting agency, and State in relation to data standards for grant reporting. The Secretary refers to the head of the standard-setting agency, which is designated by the Executive department issuing the most Federal awards. The Secretary and the Director will establish Governmentwide data standards for information reported by recipients of Federal awards within one year of the enactment of this chapter. The data standards will include standard definitions for data elements and unique identifiers for Federal awards and entities receiving them. The scope of the data standards may cover any information required to be reported to any agency by recipients of Federal awards. The data standards required under this chapter aim to make information reported by recipients of Federal awards searchable, machine-readable, nonproprietary, and consistent with accounting principles. Consultation will be conducted in establishing these standards. The Secretary and the Director will consult with various stakeholders, including the Secretary of the Treasury, agency heads, recipients of Federal awards, private sector experts, the public, and State and local governments to establish data standards for grant reporting. The Secretary and the Director will issue guidance to agencies for applying data standards to reporting by recipients of Federal grants and cooperative agreements, as well as audit-related information. The guidance aims to minimize disruption to existing reporting practices and explore modern implementation opportunities. Sec. 6404 of the chapter requires agencies to implement data standards for all future grant and cooperative agreement information requests within 3 years of enactment. Exceptions can be made by the Director, with a published list including considerations for Indian Tribes. The Paperwork Reduction Act requires compliance with data standards established under section 6402, as per guidance from the Secretary and Director. A technical amendment is made to the table of chapters for subtitle V of title 31. Data Standards for Grant Reporting are outlined in section 6401. The Single Audit Act is addressed in section 4. The Director shall issue guidance requiring audit-related information reported under chapter 75 of title 31, United States Code, to be reported in an electronic form consistent with data standards established under chapter 64. SEC. 5. Consolidation of assistance-related information; publication of public information as open data. The Secretary and the Director will collect and display Federal award information as a Governmentwide dataset, with restrictions to protect sensitive data. Recipient-reported data will be published on a public portal, and exemptions under FOIA will apply. The Secretary and the Director will collect and display Federal award information as a Governmentwide dataset, with recipient-reported data published on a public portal. Exemptions under FOIA will apply to protect sensitive data. SEC. 6. EVALUATION OF NONPROPRIETARY IDENTIFIERS. The Director and the Secretary will determine the use of nonproprietary identifiers under section 6402(a)(3)(B) of title 31, United States Code. Factors considered include accessibility and cost to recipients of Federal awards. A publication and report on the determination must be made within 1 year of enactment or when data standards are established. The Director and the Secretary will submit a report to the Committees on Oversight and Government Reform and Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs explaining the reasoning for the determination made regarding the use of nonproprietary identifiers under section 6402(a)(3)(B) of title 31, United States Code. SEC. 7. DEFINITIONS. This Act defines key terms such as "agency", "Director", "Federal award", and "Secretary". SEC. 8. RULE OF CONSTRUCTION. The Act does not mandate the collection of data not required by existing Federal laws. SEC. 9. NO ADDITIONAL FUNDS AUTHORIZED. No extra funds are allocated for implementing this Act, and existing funds will be used.
